awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research Initiation: Market-driven design concept formation in undergraduate engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
Designing successful products requires a balance of many competencies, including technical expertise and business acumen. While undergraduate engineering programs emphasize technical design and analysis, they generally do not adequately teach or discuss marketability, and evidence suggests that engineering students are graduating without a sufficient grasp of the bigger picture of design. At the same time, research in engineering design has resulted in new market-driven design techniques, which provide guidance for design practitioners regarding how to develop products that are both technically sound and marketable. This research project studies the application of market-driven design methods to engineering education, by examining how undergraduate engineering students learn design. It specifically seeks to understand how students' mental models of design develop throughout a third-year design curriculum, which introduces market-driven design concepts through course material and novel interactive tools. By learning more about students' initial mental models of design, as well as how this course influences their conceptions, this project will provide a foundational understanding and recommendations regarding holistic design education for engineers.

To bridge the gap between market-driven design and engineering education research, this proposal explores how students currently understand design as a process before and after exposing them to market-driven design approaches and tools in the context of an engineering design course. The fundamental research questions are: (1) To what extent do undergraduate engineering students' initial conceptions of design account for the market context, such as competition and consumer considerations? (2) In what ways do these design conceptions change after introducing market-driven design techniques and tools in a design course? Data from concept maps (pre- and post-instruction), student reflections on their conceptions of design, and a survey of student perceptions of the course and their understanding of design will be collected and analyzed. This will contribute to a stronger understanding of how students conceptually balance the technical and non-technical elements of design, as well as evidence regarding the value of a constructivism-based educational approach to advancing student understanding of market-driven design. In addition, these research questions will help design researchers to understand the needs of market-driven design methods, as it provides a baseline for how engineers are currently approaching design and how receptive they are to the processes and tools from the research community.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project between Virginia Tech and Stevens Institute of Technology centered on research that bridged the fields of market-driven design and engineering education to advance holistic engineering formation. The project explored undergraduate student understanding of market concepts and their relevance to engineering design decision-making. The two research questions aimed to understand: (RQ1) To what extent do undergraduate engineering students' initial conceptions of design account for the market context, such as competition and consumer considerations? and (RQ2) In what ways do these design conceptions change after introducing market-driven design techniques and tools in a design course? Data for this project were collected in the form of student pre- and post-course concept maps, weekly reflections, and post-course surveys collected in a junior level design course from 130 undergraduate students from mechanical engineering, engineering management and industrial systems engineering in Year 1 and 165 in Year 2.

The project originally set out to collect data from the engineering management and industrial systems engineering students only. However, a meeting with the advisory board at the beginning of the project led to the inclusion of mechanical engineering students in a comparative course. This inclusion of mechanical engineering expanded the project’s scope so a more comprehensive view could be explored. Overall analysis of project data demonstrated that students’ conception of design evolve when they are exposed to market features. The findings are summarized below:

Business-related terms were the most prominent in pre-course concept maps. Analyses of pre-course concept maps provided significant insights into the first research question: To what extent do undergraduate engineering students' initial conceptions of design account for the market context, such as competition and consumer considerations? The students generated free-form concept maps starting with the central node “product design,” spending 15 minutes expanding with any important concepts that came to mind in relation to the existing nodes. By categorizing all nodes in the concept maps and observing the occurrences of words in each category as a percentage of all words, we found that business-related terms account for approximately 37% of all nodes. Breaking down the subcategories of business-related terms, market-focused terms accounted for 14% of all terms. This was further split up by program, as the courses for ME and EM/ISE students covered different topics and tools. The pre-course concept maps of ME students contained 36% business terms and 14% market terms, and the EM/ISE students included 41% business terms and 13% market terms.

Post-course concept maps showed differences in the percentages of terms. Similar analyses of post-course concept maps, which involved an identical prompt but occurred at the end of the course, revealed changes in these percentages of terms. This offers some insights into RQ2: In what ways do these design conceptions change after introducing market-driven design techniques and tools in a design course? The ME students’ post-course concept maps contained 26% business terms and 11% market terms, and the EM/ISE students’ concept maps contained 45% business terms and 21% market terms. Both the major category (business) and subcategory (market) declined in frequency over the course of the ME version of the course, and both increased in frequency in the EM/ISE version of the course. There was a strong correlation between the increased terms/themes and their presence in the course syllabi, as the ME course focused more on standards and ethics whereas the EM/ISE course focused more on market research and business planning.

Students reflections indicated a change in the depth of their reflection as the semester progressed. An analysis of the correlations among data instruments was also performed, finding that written reflections are the strongest indicator of concept map changes. The week 5 written reflections, when accounting for thematic content and depth of reflection, were a significant predictor of concept maps evolving to include more consumer-related terms; this reflection took place at a point in the semester where market research and the voice of the customer were emphasized. Similarly, the week 13 reflections were an indicator of competition-related term increases, which came at a point in the semester when the student projects were focusing on business planning. Surveys of self-reported learning were not significant indicators of concept map changes.

Overall project findings showed differences in how students from the different disciplines think about design. While the project began with the intent to examine new curricular elements and tools related to market-driven design and how they contribute to student understanding, the findings showed broadly how student thinking about product design evolves throughout the courses under investigation. Mechanical Engineering students showed a decrease in the relative presence of business-related topics, whereas Engineering Management students showed an increase in these topics, specifically in market-related contents.
